moves.1. e4: Controlling the centre and giving my queen and LSB space to move.
moves.2... f6: ?! The Damiano Defence. This will allow me to mess up my opponent's position a lot. I prefer Nc3.
moves.3. Nxe5: Here is the knight sacrifice. From this point onwards, Black is in dire straits.
moves.3... fxe5: He retakes, a bit surprised at my move.
moves.4. Qh5+: Check. Here is a chance to win a pawn.
moves.4... Ke7: g6 allows me to get the rook, but this allows me to develop with tempo and wreck Black's position more.
moves.5. Qxe5+: Black is forced to do Kf7.
moves.6... Kg6: Another option was d5, but that gives away a pawn at best.
moves.7. Qf5+: Black's king is once again forced, this time to h6.
moves.7... Kh6 8. d4+: Discovered check. Qg5 is mate in one, so best is g5.
moves.9. Bxg5+: Check. I don't think that this leads to a forced mate. However Qxg5 allows me to go on a killing spree, starting with Qxf8+. Is there a move here leading to forced mate?
moves.9... Kh5: Allowing a mate in one, either by g4# or Bf7#.
moves.10. Bf7#: Checkmate! Although we are equal in material points, we aren't in position. Black's king is stuck on the side of the board and no pieces have been developed. The moral: play the Damiano Defence with caution. Please give constructive and helpful comments.
